page.title: 05The Saxon Burial Ground
page.content: The burial ground was found in 1982 when boys playing discovered a skeleton. The dig by Cleveland County Archaeological Service used labour from the Manpower Services Commission and started in March 1984. The archaeoligists in charge were Steve Sherlock and Hedley Swan. They have found 118 skeletons, 3 cremations and a series of ditches. The skeletons were buried north - south which tells us they were not Christians as they were buried east - west. The skeletons date from 550 to 600 A.D. The women were buried with brooches, pins and knives and the men with spears and shields. The cremated remains with miniature grave goods were found in large urns. Skeletons of all ages have been found but the average age was between 30 and 40.
